title: 103_s841
content:
The Act may be cited as the "False Claims Amendments Act of 1993". Government has the right to dismiss certain actions. Section 3730(b) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Government to move to dismiss the qui tam relator from the action within 60 days if the allegations were derived from an active fraud investigation or if the relator learned of the information during their employment with the United States. In cases where the employing agency has an inspector general, the person bringing the action must disclose all relevant evidence to the inspector general and notify their supervisor and the Attorney General. If the agency does not have an inspector general, the person must disclose the evidence before taking action. The person must disclose all material evidence to the Attorney General and notify their supervisor before taking action. Twelve months must pass since the disclosure for action to be taken. The Attorney General may file a motion seeking an extension of the 12-month period for action to be taken based on disclosed information. The extension can be granted for up to an additional 12 months if necessary. For a civil action, a person's supervisor must be of higher classification, have supervisory authority, and be believed to be not culpable. A motion to dismiss must include supporting documentation. The person bringing the action has the right to contest a motion to dismiss. The motion to dismiss in a civil action must be supported by evidentiary materials and will remain under seal if granted. The Department of Justice must report to the Judiciary Committees on relevant cases every 6 months. The Department of Justice must report to the Judiciary Committees every 6 months on cases where motions to dismiss were filed, their outcomes, and the status of false claims civil actions. SEC. 3 amends Section 3730 of title 31, United States Code, regarding actions barred and qui tam awards. It prohibits waiving or releasing claims for violations of section 3729, except in court-approved settlements of false claim civil actions. SEC. 4 focuses on whistleblower protection. Section 3730(h) of title 31, United States Code is amended to include whistleblower protection. Employees can seek relief if they can prove that a lawful act was a contributing factor in the employer's action against them. The employer can avoid liability if they can show with clear and convincing evidence that the same action would have been taken regardless of the lawful act. SEC. 5. DEFINITION OF PERSON: The term 'person' includes natural persons, partnerships, corporations, associations, and legal entities, including States and political subdivisions.

SEC. 6. STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS: A civil action under section 3730 must be filed within 6 years of the violation of section 3729. The period excludes times when material facts were unknown to the relevant US official. SEC. 7. AUTHORITY TO ISSUE INVESTIGATIVE DEMANDS. Section 3733 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include "or an Assistant Attorney General" after "Attorney General" in various subsections. Section 3733 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include "or an Assistant Attorney General" after "Attorney General" in various subsections, such as subsections (b)(2), (h)(6), (i), and (l)(6). SEC. 8. APPLICABILITY AND EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments made by this Act will take effect upon enactment and apply to cases filed on or after that date. Provisions regarding specific sections of the United States Code will apply to pending cases at the time of enactment. The Government may file a motion to dismiss a qui tam relator within 120 days of enactment in cases where it has elected to proceed with the action. The False Claims Amendments Act of 1986 and the Major Fraud Act of 1988 amendments apply to cases filed on or after their respective enactment dates, as well as to pending cases still ongoing at the time of enactment of the new Act.
